title: Don't force-enable frame pointers when generating debug info

labels.name: A-debuginfo
labels.description: Area: Debugging information in compiled programs (DWARF, PDB, etc.)

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: C-tracking-issue
labels.description: Category: A tracking issue for an RFC or an unstable feature.

body:
In https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47152, we [decided](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47152#issuecomment-358375205) to add a flag to force enable frame pointers (that is, to prevent the compiler from optimizing them away). This flag was to be insta-stable because it is needed, e.g. to help profilers like `perf` that need to reconstruct the stack. @dotdash then came back with a [few proposed changes](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47152#issuecomment-364910622). Unfortunately, they were never able to finalize the rebase, and the PR was closed by triage for inactivity. This is where **you** come in, dear reader! Perhaps you can help us!

There was some dispute about what the final interface ought to be though. @dotdash proposed `-Comit-frame-pointer=[yes|no]`, but @Mark-Simulacrum [proposed](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47152#issuecomment-365140301) `-Cframe-pointers=[auto, yes, no]`, which seems logical enough. 

However we say it, the default behavior (when user says nothing) probably wants to be:

- If debuginfo is enabled, keep them.
- If not optimizing, keep them.
- Follow behavior of either gcc or clang:
    - GCC has the -fomit-frame-pointer option, default off on "32-bit GNU/Linux x86 and 32-bit Darwin x86 targets", but otherwise on it seems if optimizing. 
    - [clang always retains frame pointers on darwin by default](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47152#issuecomment-364987321)
    - [cl.exe will always keep frame pointers by default for unoptimized builds](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47152#issuecomment-365145882)
